l try to adapt WPI‚Äôs official code to Command-Based , but when l simulate it ,it just crashed. The error is below :

image1456√ó848 97.4 KB

  • And my whole code is below :
    Swerve.zip (22.8 MB)

Can anyone help me with itÔºü

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-08-04T01:56:16.238Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":138,"reads":146,"readers_count":145,"score":719.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395368,"topic_slug":"the-problem-when-adapting-wpis-official-swerve-code-to-command-based","display_username":"Daniel Wenbo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/1/d1ca78a218470f87237a6011df64829d9e9f4663.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"/uploads/short-url/7BNOmtRTQbBsD11iqWJL9RouTcd.zip","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48748,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/the-problem-when-adapting-wpis-official-swerve-code-to-command-based/395368/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2963949,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-04T02:38:28.597Z","cooked":"

While Java is well known for hard to decipher error messages, in this instance it is fairly well spelled out.

Error at frc.robot.RobotContainer.<init>(RobotContainer.java:37): Unhandled exception: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Default commands must require their subsystem!

Namely RobotContainer.java:37 and Default commands must require their subsystem!

On line 37 of your RobotContainer class is:

m_swerve.setDefaultCommand(new driveWithJoystick());

You are trying to set the default command for your m_swerve. That is, the command that will run if no other commands requiring m_swerve are running.

The key word there is requiring. In Command Based, the scheduler handles running Commands, and those Commands interact with subsystems. So to stop potential issues, Commands must specify which subsystems they require (generally those the Command intends to manipulate, not simply read from), so that the Scheduler will know if more than one Command for a Subsystem has been scheduled and respond accordingly, which by default is interrupting the older Command and starting the newer Command.

However, nowhere in your driveWithJoystick class, or elsewhere, are you specifying what Subsystem object the Command requires. Going through the Subsystem Object‚Äôs .setDefaultCommand() method doesn‚Äôt actually set the requirement, you must ensure you are doing that.

The conventional way to do this with the current Command-Based Paradigm is to pass the Subsystem object into the Command as an argument to the Constructor, and have the Command save that passed object to a variable in the Command object to both interact with it and set the requirement. Like so:

In RobotContainer

m_swerve.setDefaultCommand(new driveWithJoystick(m_swerve));

in driveWithJoystick

private Drivetrain m_subsystem;

/** Creates a new driveWithJoystick. */
  public driveWithJoystick(Drivetrain subsystem) {
    // Use addRequirements() here to declare subsystem dependencies.
    m_subsystem = subsystem;
    addRequirements(m_subsystem);
  }

and then later in the Command you can use m_subsystem.driveWithJoystick(true); instead of making everything static and reaching all over the place for objects in other Classes. Similarly you can use Lambda functions to pass in joystick functions and such to Commands to use within the commands instead of making your Joysticks Public and further complicating how inter-connected your code is.

I recommend reading through the documentation on WPILIB‚Äôs site about Command Based Programming:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Command-Based Programming

This sequence of articles serves as an introduction to and reference for the WPILib command-based framework. For a collection of example projects using the command-based framework, see Command-Base...

as well as looking at some of the Command-Based examples provided to see how they handle Commands and their external Subsystem and Input requirements:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

WPILib Example Projects

WPILib example projects demonstrate a large number of library features and use patterns. Projects range from simple demonstrations of a single functionality to complete, competition-capable robot p...

Thanks a lot , in a nutshell, l juts forget to use addRequiremens() to define which subsystem it will use . But is there some disadvantages if l define subsystems in RobotContainer and use it from Robotcontainer?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-08-04T02:58:53.645Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":101,"readers_count":100,"score":35.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395368,"topic_slug":"the-problem-when-adapting-wpis-official-swerve-code-to-command-based","display_username":"Daniel Wenbo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16897,"username":"ExploitSage","name":"Mykah","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48748,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/the-problem-when-adapting-wpis-official-swerve-code-to-command-based/395368/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2963953,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-04T03:14:49.345Z","cooked":"

The disadvantages are mostly just in that it is considered bad practice. In the past we just made everything static and directly referenced it from other classes, and it does work, but WPILIB has tried to move away from that because it forms bad habits for students, especially those who may want to go on to work in a field involving Software Development, much like I did after I graduated High School.

In Computer Science and Software Engineering there are these concepts of Coupling and Cohesion. Cohesion is an important concept, but Coupling is the more relevant one in this particular instance. Its the measure of how much any one ‚Äúmodule‚Äù or ‚Äúunit‚Äù of code (often ‚ÄúClasses‚Äù are used as this unit in Java) is dependent or reliant on other to be able to function. Generally, good practice is to have as loose coupling as is reasonable. Here is a great read on the subjects: Coupling and Cohesion

So by having Classes reaching directly into other Classes, or all into one central class, you have made everything very highly Coupled, which while in an FRC bot where you work on it for a couple months and its done, isn‚Äôt a big deal, applying that same practice to a real software project that will need to be supported for years or decades is going to make things much harder to maintain and extend as time goes on. So you are better served from an educational standpoint (which to me is much more important than the robot itself), to learn the modern methods of developing software, than just using the quick and dirty, get it done, method.

So by passing in requirements externally you create more flexible ‚Äúmodules‚Äù that can be viewed more as independent parts of a bigger picture of the code structure rather than as one whole, completely interlocked unit.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-08-04T05:27:09.112Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":21.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395368,"topic_slug":"the-problem-when-adapting-wpis-official-swerve-code-to-command-based","display_username":"Daniel Wenbo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16897,"username":"ExploitSage","name":"Mykah","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48748,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/the-problem-when-adapting-wpis-official-swerve-code-to-command-based/395368/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2963974,"name":"Carlos Gross Jones","username":"CarlosGJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carlosgj/{size}/131747_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-04T05:35:25.666Z","cooked":"
ExploitSage:

it forms bad habits for students, especially those who may want to go on to work in a field involving Software Development, much like I did after I graduated High School.

It‚Äôs worth noting that this is only partially true. In the normal kind of mainstream, desktop software development, definitely. However, in a lot of embedded-heavy fields (industrial, aerospace, automotive) where reliability and determinism are more important than extensibility, there‚Äôs still a ton of development being done in C89 with static memory allocation.

Well, and now l am puzzled that should l put the xboxcontroller in the RobotContainer or in the Drivetrain subsystem ? l need to use XboxController in the Drivetrain , but l think put it in the RobotContainer is no so suit , and l want to ask what‚Äôs the mainstream solution?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2021-08-04T05:45:57.014Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":75,"readers_count":74,"score":25.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":395368,"topic_slug":"the-problem-when-adapting-wpis-official-swerve-code-to-command-based","display_username":"Daniel Wenbo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16897,"username":"ExploitSage","name":"Mykah","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48748,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/the-problem-when-adapting-wpis-official-swerve-code-to-command-based/395368/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2963983,"name":null,"username":"Starlight220","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/starlight220/{size}/150872_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-04T06:56:03.266Z","cooked":"

The RobotContainer class replaces the OI class from the old project layout, and all joysticks should be there.

For most use cases, binding commands to buttons using the Trigger API will be much better.

If it doesn‚Äôt fit your use case and you want to pass information to commands (and through them to subsystems), pass it as suppliers and similar (with lambdas). For example, to pass a button as a data source you‚Äôll want to do this:

BooleanSupplier buttonSource = () -> xbox.getAButton();

boolean currentButtonState = buttonSource.getAsBoolean();

This decouples the code even more, as you can pass a different supplier when testing or updating the code.

6738 used the Trigger API, suppliers, etc a lot for 2021; feel free to look at our code. A relevant example:

github.com

ExcaliburFRC/IR2021/blob/main/src/main/java/io/excaliburfrc/robot/RobotContainer.java#L124-L134

    

  1. new JoystickButton(armJoystick, startShootButton)
    2. 

  2.     .toggleWhenPressed(
    3. 

  3.         superstructure.shoot(
    4. 

  4.             () -> armJoystick.getRawButton(shootButton),
    5. 

  5.             () -> armJoystick.getRawButton(ejectButton),
    6. 

  6.             drivetrain));
    7. 

  7. new JoystickButton(armJoystick, startDummyShootButton)
    8. 

  8.     .toggleWhenPressed(
    9. 

  9.         superstructure.dummyShoot(
    10. 

  10.             () -> armJoystick.getRawButton(shootButton),
    11. 

  11.             () -> armJoystick.getRawButton(ejectButton)));
    12.
github.com

ExcaliburFRC/IR2021/blob/main/src/main/java/io/excaliburfrc/robot/subsystems/SuperStructure.java#L105-L123

    

  1. public Command shoot(BooleanSupplier trigger, BooleanSupplier eject, Drivetrain drive) {
    2. 

  2.   // constantly align drive
    3. 

  3.   Command dtpid = drive.goToAngle(vision::getYawOffset, 0);
    4. 

  4.   // spinup based on distance, and check if drive is aligned
    5. 

  5.   Command shooterpid =
    6. 

  6.       new ShootCommand(trigger, drive::isAtTargetAngle, eject, vision::getDistance);
    7. 

  7.   // the most important part - LEDs!
    8. 

  8.   var leds = new InstantCommand(() -> LEDs.INSTANCE.setMode(LedMode.GREEN));
    9. 

  9.   return new ParallelCommandGroup(dtpid, shooterpid, leds);
    10. 

  10. }
    11. 

  11. 

  12. public Command dummyShoot(BooleanSupplier trigger, BooleanSupplier eject) {
    13. 

  13.   // make it seem as if drive is always aligned
    14. 

  14.   // spinup to 80 rps
    15. 

  15.   Command shooterpid = new ShootCommand(trigger, () -> true, eject, 80);
    16. 

  16.   // the most important part - LEDs!
    17. 

  17.   var leds = new InstantCommand(() -> LEDs.INSTANCE.setMode(LedMode.GREEN));
    18. 

  18.   return new ParallelCommandGroup(shooterpid, leds);
    19. 

  19. }
    20.
